VIETNAMESE
BUDDHISM
MONTHLY
ISSUE 2 RELEASED ON SEPTEMBER 15, YEAR OF THE MONKEY

PUBLISHED BY THE REGULAR ASSOCIATION OF VIETNAMESE BUDDHISM

Buddhism

Vietnam

Contents Issue 2

Full Moon of the Ninth Month of the Year of the Monkey

Authors

The page is intentionally left blank to mark the space for reflection and contemplation.
In this silence, we allow the mind to rest and the heart to open, welcoming the
teachings yet to come. It is a moment of pause in our journey through the pages of the
"Journal of Vietnamese Buddhism."

In the tradition of Vietnamese Buddhism, the blank page is not a void, but a space filled
with potential. It invites us to be present, to breathe, and to find peace in the
simplicity of being. Let this page be a gentle reminder of the power of stillness and
the wisdom that arises from within.

From ancient times, humanity has been engaged in a struggle. Due to a karmic affinity
from time immemorial, humans possess a physical body existing in a universe, amidst a
human society, alongside countless other sentient beings. Having life means preserving
life, whether through consciousness or instinct.

Heat, cold, wind, rain, hunger, cold, wild beasts, disasters... all these are challenges
humans need to overcome to survive. Nature is an enemy, but also a friend. When we are
weak, nature threatens; when we are clever, nature serves. With two hands and a mind,
humans have exploited nature, utilized nature, and compelled nature to provide the
necessities of life.

From the economic lifestyle of gathering to the economic lifestyle of herding and
cultivation, humanity has truly advanced. But from the beginning, the object of struggle
was not only nature and wild beasts. Humans have consumed each other like beasts
devouring humans; thus, from ancient times, people have sought ways to cope with their
fellow beings.

Five or seven individuals banded together, using the strength of unity to protect one
another. Tribes were formed, and thus, the struggle against nature became more
effective. The tribal system marked a step forward for humanity on the path of survival.
These human groups developed laws, customs, rituals, entertainment, and unique survival
methods. They had culture.

From the tribal organization, humanity gradually moved toward the organization of
nations. During this period, intellect expanded, and the consciousness of kinship
swiftly developed. The phenomenon of humans eating humans did not frequently occur
anymore: now, humans directed all their mental and physical energies towards exploiting
nature.

Yet the more nature was exploited, the more resources and food it provided.
Simultaneously, technological advancements occurred: the scope of exploitation and
production expanded at an unimaginable pace. Economic issues suddenly became critical.
Conflicts erupted between nations and between social classes. War broke out fiercely.
Science and technology turned to serve war, producing bombs, bullets, and weaponry.
While struggling against nature, humans turned their weapons against each other.

People died, blood spilled, flesh torn. In the past, with limited means of production and
crude tools, humanity did not die in such numbers as now. All human greed and anger have
been awakened; people have used many malicious schemes to confront one another. Killing
fellow humans? Never mind. As long as it serves the class, satisfies personal desires.
People kill under the guise of ideals: killing to eliminate disease, to build peace. To
counteract killings, naturally, the opposing side must also resort to killing...

In the past, a black savage eating a white person was called barbaric. Today, a nation
with bombs that can kill more people than any other is called civilized. In truth, this
is nothing more than a horrific barbarity.

Previously, the direction of culture was a struggle against nature. Now, the direction of
culture is a struggle against fellow humans.

In a field of fierce and vast struggle, using harm to prevent harm is an illusion that
cannot be achieved. The law of cause and effect never errs: sow the wind and reap the
storm, plant corn and harvest corn, plant beans and receive beans, and if one sows harm,
they will endure the consequences of harm.

Humans must be conscious of this crucial point and must acknowledge that culture has lost
its way.

People need to see that desires of greed and anger have caused chaos in the world and
must return to themselves to initiate a great purification within their inner realm.
They must be aware that they contain elements of wisdom and compassion, but also
elements of delusion and desire.

Delusional desires have obscured compassion and wisdom: humans must strive to eliminate
them, to nurture wisdom and compassion. With wisdom and compassion, humans can attain
happiness and can unite deeply to create a beautiful shared life.

In the past, culture shifted from struggling with nature to struggling with fellow
humans. The direction of the new culture of humanity must be a struggle with personal
desires.

The issue of the value of human beings is a crucial issue for existence. As long as this
issue is not resolved, people cannot find peace of mind to establish their destiny.
Solving this problem allows humans to have a firm standpoint and a decisive attitude
towards their own liberation.

What is the value of human beings and what can they do with all their inherent abilities?
The element that determines all aspects of life lies within humans or somewhere else?
These are fundamental questions. People can achieve peace and happiness, everyone
believes so and wants to believe so. But how to achieve it? What means to use, and where
to place trust?

Since ancient times, humanity has lived under the threats of nature. Frightened by
phenomena like water, fire, and lightning, humans have long submitted to supernatural
forces they believe lurk everywhere. Offering prayers to wish for blessings and avoid
disasters represents complete submission: humans placed themselves under the protection
of ghosts and deities, feeling that all their successes and failures are decided by
these divine beings. If the deities are pleased, then success ensues; if angered, then
ruin follows. Thus, the thought of bribery emerged, and people thought that just some
offerings could win the favor of the deities.

Once everything in life is acknowledged as decided by deities, humans must always live in
fear, not daring to make any decisions on their own. Therefore, divination arises,
seeking the guidance of divine beings. Here, the value of humans is truly minimal.

As intellect developed, humanity, through philosophical reasoning, arrived at a more
refined concept of belief. Polytheism gradually gave way to monotheism, and instead of
believing in mixed forces, people turned to believe in a single omnipotent, omniscient
divine being who arranges all matters in life. Those who receive the favor of this
divine being will have happiness and be liberated from suffering. Here, humans no longer
engage in the ridiculous bribery of the past and have learned about the necessary
virtues. However, their minds are still placed in a distant world, and when they seek
the divine, they fully believe that only the divine they pray to can bestow blessings
and save them from suffering. The value of humans here is not much higher. If everything
is arranged by the divine, then humans, with a mind and two hands, hold no significant
position in life.

The day science emerged, humanity shifted its trust somewhat. People no longer looked up
to the heavens with hope but placed their trust in the fairy of science, which was
unveiling marvelous wonders. Many were ready to deny all else, only to hope and trust in
science. But as science advanced, so did technology; once Western societies mechanized,
Eastern societies followed. The issues of production and consumption gave rise to
overall competition. Humans became somewhat mechanical when living in a mechanized
society; economic competition sparked wars. Wars demand weapons, and science was
immediately driven to produce killing tools. The birth of the atomic bomb is a
terrifying threat.

The latest scientific inventions today are being applied to the act of killing. Science
has become a perilous double-edged sword. It is a monster nurtured by humans, now
threatening them. Just one small mistake, and humans could be annihilated by it.

Abandoning science is madness because science can serve humanity effectively. But placing
faith in it as one would in divine power is a grave mistake. Science is only a product
of a mind guided by dark desires. Excessive faith in it means humans have forgotten
themselves, that is, have denied all the beautiful values they inherently possess.

Alongside those who blindly trust in science, there are those who blindly trust in
principles and organizations. In today's society, people have beautiful principles to
broadly ensure rights and freedom. Humans boast of having complete, rational
organizations. However, no matter how many beautiful principles and organizations exist,
humans still do not see any progress on the path to happiness. People rely on having
beautiful principles and organizations and think that applying them will lead to
success. No! Reality has proven that principles and organizations alone are not
sufficient. To implement them, there must be humans worthy of being called humans. A
constitution alone cannot guarantee the future of a nation! To ensure the implementation
of that constitution, there must be worthy parliaments with talent and virtue. Here,
humans are forgotten, and the true value of humans has been diminished.

Trusting in principles or organizations is not much different from trusting in lifeless
material. Moreover, people are sometimes easily deceived by words and language. After
the great wars, charters and declarations spread everywhere. Freedom, equality,
liberation, happiness, independence... so many beautiful words like the dawn on the
horizon were put forth. Every great nation in the world wants to be a leader, a
benefactor, a savior of humanity. But in the end, those "nominal but unreal" farces
gradually sow doubt among the masses, and, in the words of a certain writer, all the
leaflets and banners released with beautiful words ultimately fail to mend the deep
wounds that history has called bewilderment.

All the suffering of humanity, in fact, stems from misplaced beliefs. From belief in
deities to belief in science, principles, organizations, and beautiful words, humans
have indeed somewhat denied their value. Humans have forgotten themselves to seek
happiness in forces outside of themselves.

All the successes and failures of humans must be created by humans themselves. Humans
determine their fate.

The individual is fully responsible for self-liberation. Whether society is good or life
is happy depends on the individual.

Indeed, human beings possess the highest value. Yet for a long time, people have
neglected this. People are not nurtured, cultivated, or trained. While humans become
increasingly corrupt, they still believe that skilled hands can build happiness with
those tools.

The status and value of humans have indeed become clear. If we do not rely on values
outside of humanity, we must recognize this value and act accordingly. Conscious of
their value and role, individuals must strive to self-train, transform themselves, and
find happiness through their own actions. Whenever relying on external forces fails,
humans have believed that the crucial issue is to hone tools. But now, the tools are
sharp, and people fear their own creations, claiming that tools have become too
sophisticated. Thus, it is time to cultivate virtues, so that when individuals become
good, society and the universe will also become good. The outward and true aspects of
karma are two dimensions of karmic result; recognizing human value is essential to
trusting in the professional ability of everyone to create.

Training individuals is the most urgent task of our era.

Born into a bureaucratic family, Nguyễn Công Trứ had to endure days of poverty and
darkness. His father, Đức Ngạn Hầu, led the Cần Vương uprising against the Tây Sơn.
After King Lê Chiêu Thống fled to China, the movement disbanded, and Đức Ngạn Hầu
returned to his hometown in disillusionment, living a mundane life as a village scholar.
Consequently, Nguyễn Công Trứ, following his father, experienced poverty throughout his
youth.

However, this impoverished circumstance did not discourage Nguyễn Công Trứ. He strove to
rise above it, to create a remarkable career. In the struggle with reality, this
Confucian scholar endured many hardships, but ultimately, he overcame his circumstances
and succeeded brilliantly.

Many other scholars, like Cao Bá Quát, Trần Tế Xương, and others, tasted bitter failures
in their careers. But Nguyễn Công Trứ succeeded. We must ask what factor determined this
success?

Poverty brought Nguyễn many hardships. The image of this poverty is vividly depicted in
his poem "Hàn Nho Phong Vị Phú":

This truly is a scene of desolation! The circumstances of a knowledgeable scholar are
indeed moving, yet the situation of "destitution and adversity" of Nguyễn Công Trứ makes
us deeply understand his bitter toil:

Due to poverty, Nguyễn Công Trứ had to devise various strategies and sometimes even
considered becoming a geomancer or doctor to make ends meet. But as a scholar harboring
dreams of social status and fame, proud of his exceptional character and morality, he
ultimately did not resort to those desperate means, and returned to daily deprivation:

However, Nguyễn Công Trứ's poverty was not like any other poverty. Because
psychologically, Nguyễn Công Trứ was acutely aware of his poverty. More than anyone, he
knew he was a "gentleman," a "hero":

Yet after many exams, the scholarly debt remained unpaid! Nonetheless, Nguyễn Công Trứ
was not discouraged. He consoled himself that fame did not need to be rushed; if one has
a body, one must have a name, and if the body exists, fame will eventually follow.
Occasionally, he felt melancholic over delayed recognition, but this did not dampen his
spirit.

Cao Bá Quát and Trần Tế Xương later found themselves in similar situations, but lacking
firm awareness of timing, they failed to maintain their resolve. Cao, after many exam
failures, became pessimistic and disheartened. These continuous failures darkened Cao Bá
Quát's soul, and being a person full of emotions, he allowed sorrow to dominate his
spirit. The hardships made him suffer, discontent arose, and finally, his obstinate and
angry temperament led to failure. Trần Tế Xương also struggled with exams and craved
fame as much as anyone. He lived through poverty like Nguyễn, but being quick-tempered
and easily discouraged, he angrily mocked others. Mr. Tú Vị-Xuyên truly lacked the
demeanor of a true scholar. Observe his petty annoyance when envying those who passed
the exams:

Yet, he did not stop there! He mocked those who passed the exams, satirized the
examiners. All because he failed! If he had passed, perhaps he would not have mocked
them like that! Nguyễn Công Trứ was quite different. Despite poverty, hardship, and many
failures, he maintained the necessary demeanor of a true scholar. Admittedly, social
customs were not beautiful; wealth was valued, and righteousness was scorned, yet he
carefully upheld his character:

And because of this, often the gentleman and the hero must feign ignorance, play deaf and
dumb to endure the hardship. How pitiable for the scholar:

It was only poverty! But the suffering did not end there: added to the misery of poverty
was the suffering of human relations. Nguyễn Công Trứ lamented that in life, only money
mattered. All flaws and failures stemmed from a lack of money. With money, one could buy
the affection of the world:

Truly bitter and disappointing. Pride was sometimes heavily wounded, and character often
had to be lowered: those were moments when Nguyễn Công Trứ had to humble himself to
please the coarse rich, always knowing only money:

So often Nguyễn Công Trứ got frustrated and bitterly cursed his poverty:

However, this frustration did not drive Nguyễn Công Trứ to recklessness. Poverty did not
weaken his will; on the contrary, it forged his resolve to become more enduring. In his
heart, Nguyễn Công Trứ always longed to rise and achieve a remarkable career. What that
career was, even he was not clearly aware of at first. Nguyễn Công Trứ initially only
wished to pass the exams. Passing would mean escaping poverty and having the means to
benefit the country and the people. How to benefit the country and the people would be
figured out later; for now, passing was enough.

Thus, the career that Nguyễn Công Trứ dreamed of achieving was primarily fame. He devoted
all his attention to the exams. Amid poverty, he patiently hoped for the day his name
would adorn the golden list:

After many failures, people often trust in fate. Nguyễn Công Trứ also believed in fate,
but here fate was not a harsh destiny. Being a hero means that fate is not to remain in
poverty forever. A gentleman is born to assist the country and its people; if not yet
prominent, it's because the time has not come, and any hero must endure poverty first:

In addition to this belief, there was faith in the cycle of things. Life does not always
remain the same; everything changes, moving from hardship to prosperity, from
flourishing to decline. Nguyễn Công Trứ did not believe he would remain in this state of
hardship forever. Believing in the cycle, he never fell into pessimism because hope
remained alive in his heart:

Thus, Nguyễn Công Trứ patiently awaited:

The "time" Nguyễn Công Trứ considered was not some sacred, metaphysical factor, but the
time that determines success. Why hadn't he passed? Because the time had not come. So,
what is "time"? Certainly, he did not consider it the period when heaven and earth had
yet to allow him to pass. No! "Time" was merely the shadow of change. If not this exam,
then the next, or the one after that. Exams have failures and successes, that is
natural. Nguyễn Công Trứ believed as we Buddhists believe in karma. Everything stems
from humans; humans create and receive, with no divine intervention in human affairs.

Believing this, Nguyễn Công Trứ lived a life of purity and simplicity. He did not become
reckless like Cao Bá Quát, nor did he become irritable and lose his scholarly demeanor
like Trần Tế Xương. Nguyễn Công Trứ remained calm, content to follow the way, waiting
for misfortune to turn to fortune. He knew well that "full stomach becomes Buddha, empty
stomach becomes ghost," but he was determined not to...

To those of lesser character, patience in maintaining the path is key, knowing that
steadfastness will inevitably lead to success.

In conversations with descendants about the past, he often recited the phrase "joy in the
way of poverty". In discussions with brothers about worldly affairs, he would quote "to
be human is not to be wealthy". Yet Nguyễn Công Trứ truly succeeded: At the age of 42,
he passed the regional examination, was appointed to various positions including
Historical Records Officer, and was eventually promoted to Minister of War. His modern
fame allowed him to help the country and its people, quelling uprisings and helping
reclaim tens of thousands of acres of arable land, establishing prosperous areas such as
Kim Sơn and Tiền Hải.

All these grand achievements were possible due to his intense faith in himself. Nguyễn Du
embraced lonely loyalty, entrusting everything to the heavens, surrendering his fate.
Cao Bá Quát placed too much trust in strategy, unable to endure trials of integrity,
disregarding virtue. Trần Tế Xương, after many failures, blamed society and people,
asserting that his failure was due to a corrupt society, not realizing he himself lacked
the conditions for success. Only Nguyễn Công Trứ held firm belief in the law of cause
and effect, and in his own strength. This faith was the most crucial element in his
success. This is what Nguyễn Du, Cao Bá Quát, and Trần Tế Xương lacked. Success or
failure here was not due to divine or social factors, but a psychological one. Believing
in one's abilities and in karma's law, Nguyễn Công Trứ achieved success. Thanks to this
belief, he avoided falling into pessimism, maintained his demeanor, and preserved his
character. Beautiful causes lead to beautiful effects; a noble life of virtue and
continuous effort naturally led Nguyễn Công Trứ to the highest levels of success.

Buddhism is a religion founded over twenty centuries ago. The foundation of its doctrine
is not just one or two scriptures but a vast treasure trove of rich texts. This
abundance has only increased over time. The earliest works required extensive research.

Buddhist literature is the study of the entire corpus of Buddhist texts across eras and
sects. Here, we do not claim the grand endeavor that is beyond the capacity of a few
individuals. We only present, according to our shallow understanding, the general
features of Vietnamese Buddhist literature. If our work helps readers gain a general
understanding of Buddhist literature, we are satisfied. First, we present the content of
Buddhist literature, then its history and teachings, introducing significant works, and
providing an overview of its doctrinal systems. Finally, we dedicate a chapter to
Vietnamese Buddhist works across various dynasties.

Next to the Bodhi Society is a Tibetan temple, built by Tibetan monks. Currently, there
are Chinese monks practicing Tantric Buddhism living there. Beside the temple, there is
a guesthouse for visitors to stay.

By the roadside, behind a plot of land with a stupa, there is a Chinese nunnery known as
"Chung-Hoa Great Enlightenment Temple," built by a Chinese nun. The couplets in front of
the temple are:

The Great Vehicle transports the three wheels, universally saving sentient beings beyond
eons
All propagate the wondrous Dharma, the Vajra stupa revives the bridge.

This temple venerates a stone Buddha statue over a meter tall. This stone statue was
discovered when people were digging a trench in front of the temple, and the residing
nun brought it in to be painted and worshipped.

For a long time, I have desired to visit the Nairanjana River of our Buddhist followers.
The sacred river where, in the past, the Buddha, after using milk, placed his bowl,
which floated upstream; the historical river that once washed away the dust from the
Buddha's body before he sat under the Bodhi tree to attain enlightenment.

Here it is, the historical river appearing before my eyes. Along the road to the Bodhi
stupa, about 100 meters from the white sandy bank, the river flows sluggishly. The river
is very shallow now, and people can cross without needing a boat, just by rolling up
their pants. The scenery here is very simple. The river is shallow. Crossing the river
needs no boat. Looking at the river, I feel my heart at ease. Just that is enough to
fulfill my wish!

After visiting the Bodhi stupa, we returned to the residence of the Buddhist monks at
Dien-Dien. We briefly inquired about the current state of Buddhism in Dien-Dien. The
monks informed us that the government of Dien-Dien is very devotedly supporting Buddhism
in both spiritual and material aspects.

There are about 80,000 monks, an estimated 10 million followers, and approximately 4,000
temples in Dien-Dien.

The monks practice meditation from the time they receive Sa-di ordination until they
reach the age of twenty.

BUDDHISM
and
SCIENCE

(Continued)

Mathematical formulas often accompany measurements, always containing some degree of
uncertainty. When measuring a table, for instance, I might say the table is one meter
long with a relative error of 1/100, meaning it could be between 0.99m and 1.01m, but I
can never know its exact length. The more precise the measurements, the more
comprehensive the laws discovered can encompass various phenomena. Today, science can
measure with a relative error of one part in ten million for length and even more
accurately for weight, which allows for the exploration of subtle phenomena, paving the
way to a rich understanding of quantum concepts.

Based on measurements, science has a very distinct scope. It only examines phenomena
within the realm of sensory verification, whether direct or indirect. For instance, to
observe invisible rays, scientists find a way to make them visible on photographic paper
or chemical plates. Beyond this scope, a scientist does not concern themselves. This
statement is not meant to criticize their perspective as narrow but to clearly
distinguish what Science is. Furthermore, this scope is already vast, and even a small
part of it can occupy the minds of a generation. Once this scope has been thoroughly
explored, how can one help but be moved to consider issues beyond it? For even
scientists are human, with questions about the mysterious essence of life. Therefore, it
is no surprise that science has become the foundation for profound philosophies that
require more than just reading popular books; indeed, one must study some advanced
mathematics and physics.

These philosophies not only apply new scientific discoveries but also largely rely on
the unique characteristics of science. I would like to sequentially highlight a few key
characteristics to conveniently explain the connections in the final section.

We arrive here
Amidst a vibrant spring,
The heart of the world feels anew,
Joy rises in the heart of the twentieth century.
The mountain peaks tremble, a child opens a smile,
A heart filled with bliss,
Walking with mother to the pagoda to worship Buddha,
Offering a bouquet of fresh roses,
The gray robes flutter above the waves of people.

A genuine heart

Wrapped in an old robe.

Laughter echoes amidst the days of toil.

Simple meals, stale broth.

Today, a day of offering to the Buddha, the heart finds peace.

A pure heart,

Calmly witnessing the world’s fluctuations.

Here, the temple provides warmth,

Here, distant from the fires of war,

Here, all grievances fade away,

Oh, how beautiful, dear neighbors!

Oh, great Compassionate Father of humanity!

Here, the heart warms gently,

The pain dries and eases...

Vitality awakens within the blood,

The century joyously speaks but stutters.

Rich and poor share the same pillow,

Endless joy, the light of the Dharma spreads far and wide.

Here and there, the season of the Dharma rises,

People feel the connection already!

Bright eyes, a graceful smile,

And here, a new spring blooms freshly.

Dear Chu Tam-Kien,

I have been in Saigon for five days now, and only today have I found the time to write to
you. The delay is because I was busy arranging accommodation and finding a school.
Everything is settled now, uncle. I am currently staying with a friend in Dakao. This
friend studied in Hue before, attending the same class as me. His name is Hien, and he
has a very amiable nature. Initially, I planned to go to An-Quang temple and ask Master
Minh-Tue for help finding a place, but I happened to meet Hien on the street. When Hien
learned I was looking for lodging, he immediately invited me to his home and asked his
parents if I could stay there happily. Hien's parents were very welcoming and insisted I
stay. I was hesitant, but Hien assured me that I could pay for my stay, so there was no
need to worry.

Thus, I have a place to stay and a good friend. As for school, Hien helped me find one.
It turned out that Hien is also in his second year, like me, and advised me to attend
the same school as him. I audited classes for two days and found the professors to be
excellent, so I officially enrolled. The school is Phuong-Duc, right in the city's
center.

Yesterday was Sunday, so I visited An Quang temple but could not meet Master Minh Tue. I
heard he was busy teaching the Dharma to the Buddhist family at Phuoc-Hoa temple. I
asked a novice monk to show me around the temple. It turns out this is a Buddhist
school, uncle.

According to the novice monk, this temple was built in 1949. Being in the city, it does
not have the almost absolute tranquility I found in the temples in Hue. Here, I found
many familiar things: the gentle demeanor of the monks, the friendly and kind smiles of
the young monks, the soothing atmosphere filled with the faint scent of incense...
Previously, I thought that leaving Hue meant I could no longer experience the serene,
mystical hours under the beloved roofs of Bao Quoc and Tu Dam temples. Here, I realized
that throughout Vietnam, everywhere is illuminated by the light of Compassion, and
genuine Buddhists can create a peaceful atmosphere to live under the Compassionate
Buddha’s shadow.

As I mentioned, An Quang temple is also a Buddhist school, like Bao Quoc temple. Thus,
there are three Buddhist schools in Vietnam: Hue, Nhatrang, and Saigon. I heard that in
the South, there are two other Buddhist schools: Van Thu Buddhist Institute, managed by
the Northern Buddhist Congregation, and Giac-Nguyen Buddhist School, supervised by
Venerable Hanh Tru. On a free day, I will visit those places, uncle, and I will tell you
about them later.

Now, let me continue talking about An-Quang temple, the Buddhist school of Southern
Vietnam.

When I first entered the temple gate, I immediately felt joyful and recognized many
familiar features. The front hall resembled Tu Dam temple exactly, and surprisingly,
there were still the same couplets from Tu Dam temple that one day, standing before the
temple gate, you explained to me:

* The Buddha's true teaching governs, with infinite life, infinite light, infinite
virtues,

« Study the true meaning, listen truly, think truly, practice truly *

I wandered to the guest house and there, I was received by the Abbot for almost half an
hour. Afterward, the Abbot asked a novice monk to show me around the temple. To the
right of the main hall is a long building with two classrooms, filled with young monks.
Outside, many bicycles were parked, and I learned that besides the resident students at
the Buddhist institute, many monks from other temples also come here to study.

The third-year class was having a lesson on Buddhist philosophy. Some senior monk whose
name I do not know was teaching on the Mahayana doctrines. Standing outside, I
eavesdropped for about five minutes. The teacher's voice was clear yet gentle, and I
wanted to listen indefinitely if not for the novice monk by my side. Passing by the
second-year class, I encountered a literature lesson; the young monks were studying the
"Chinh - phu - ngam," uncle. Thus, besides Buddhist philosophy, the young monks also
study common subjects like literature, science, history... I also like this because I
believe the young monks should have fundamental knowledge in all fields. I was taken to
visit the monks' quarters. It was a long, spacious building, with monks’ desks lined up
in two straight rows. Each monk had a large compartment for tools and books. Each monk
had their own bed, coat rack, and desk. The arrangement was neat and orderly; I imagined
that even secular dormitories might not be better.

I visited the distribution room for scriptures and read through the catalog. One day, I
will acquire some books to send to you. This distribution room is a room on the left
side of the ancestral house. It seems the ancestral house was recently completed; it has
two floors. The upper floor is the library and the quarters for the senior monks and
teachers. The ground floor is for worship, the office of the Director monk, and behind
it are the quarters for the monks and bhikkhus.

I asked permission to visit the main hall and pay respects to the Buddha. The main hall
was impressively solemn! The statue of Buddha Shakyamuni amazed me immensely. I had
never seen such a beautiful statue. His face was calm, full of compassion and wisdom.
His sitting posture was strong and majestic. A statue that embodies all three virtues:
compassion, wisdom, and courage is truly rare. I heard this statue was created by a
layperson who had taken the Bodhisattva vows, who is currently a professor of painting
and sculpture at the art school.

It is said that Buddhism has not yet achieved complete unification. I wonder if this is
true. Personally, when I first encountered Southern Buddhism, I found it not difficult
at all. Sitting in Ân-Quang Pagoda, talking with a student monk, I felt as if I were
sitting within the great family of Buddhists. Besides the six Buddhist organizations of
the Sect Association, there are many other groups. But I think in such a gentle and
sincere atmosphere, the groups can surely understand each other and stand side by side
to build a unified Vietnamese Buddhism, steering clear of all divisive plots from those
outside the path.

The letter has become lengthy, so I shall stop here. Wishing you joy and strength, I look
forward to writing a longer letter next time.

Your student, TÂM TUỆ

Holding a dish of salt, dipping ginger, Ginger spicy, salt salty, please do not
forsake each other. North and South share one sorrow, Love each other, how
could we part? Day and night, one steadfast heart, Remember the vow between
you and me: "When a fish gives birth atop a banyan tree, A bird gives birth
underwater, then I'll leave you. When lettuce builds a pavilion, Ironwood
sliced thin, then you'll leave me." To unite as one family, Together build
our path for eternity. Compassion, remember these words, Follow the wisdom,
cultivate body and mind. Eradicate greed, anger, arrogance, Love each other
with one thought, deep and lasting. Cleverly respond to outsiders, Chickens
from one mother should not endlessly fight. Thanks to the miraculous grace of
the Buddha, We build a lasting life forevermore.

next issue; we ask for the readers' understanding.

WORLD BUDDHIST CONFERENCE FOURTH SESSION: The General Association of Vietnamese
Buddhism has just received an invitation from the organizing committee of the Fourth
World Buddhist Conference. This conference will be held in Nepal (northern India) from
the 7th to the 14th of November, 1956. During the meeting on September 1, 1956, the
Central Executive Committee of the General Association of Vietnamese Buddhism appointed
its delegates. Among them are Venerable Tinh Khiet, the President of the General
Association of Vietnamese Buddhism, and Venerable Hue Quang, the Vice President. These
are the official delegates. Additionally, Thay Minh Chau (currently residing at the
Nalanda Buddhist Institute) and lay Buddhist Tran Thanh Hiep, the commissioner for
Buddhist art and literature in Vietnam, are also included in the delegation attending
the conference in Nepal.

Of the eight topics proposed by the World Buddhist Conference for discussion at the
Fourth World Buddhist Conference, Vietnam has selected the following two topics for
presentation:

In our view, this Fourth World Buddhist Conference has the character of a grand cultural
festival, aiming to clearly express the spiritual essence and stance of Buddhism in
contemporary society.

We are informed that besides the two topics chosen by Vietnamese Buddhism, there are
other very significant topics, such as Buddhism with Nationalism, Buddhism with
Capitalism, Buddhism with Socialism, Buddhism with Communism...

VIETNAMESE BUDDHISM

Published in Buddhist newspapers in Vietnam — Currently, the headquarters of the General
Association is located at An Quang Pagoda, 635 Van Hanh Street, Cholon, in the capital
city of Saigon, not in Hue as some mistakenly believe.

BROADCAST OF NATIONAL BUDDHISM IS BEING ORGANIZED: Besides publishing the
"Journal of Vietnamese Buddhism," the General Association is organizing a unified
Buddhist broadcast on the Saigon radio station, aiming to manifest the voice of Buddhism
nationwide. Thay Thien Hoa, the Commissioner of Dharma Propagation of the General
Association, is advancing this work. With the cooperation of the Southern Vietnam
Buddhist Radio and the Northern Vietnam Buddhist Radio in the South, we believe that the
unified Buddhist broadcast will be organized swiftly and will achieve excellent results.

A VIETNAMESE BUDDHIST INSTITUTE WILL BE CONSTRUCTED IN NHA TRANG: The Sangha
Association and the Middle Region Buddhist Association are dedicating efforts to build
an extensive Buddhist school in Nha Trang, named the "Vietnamese Buddhist Institute in
Central Vietnam." At present, the energies of both Administrative Committees are focused
on this endeavor. With the strong support of Buddhists nationwide, the institute is sure
to be completed in a short time.

ANOTHER BUDDHIST SCHOOL HAS BEEN BUILT IN TRA VINH: Under the guidance and
support of the Southern Vietnam Sangha Association and the Southern Vietnam Buddhist
Association Management Committee, the Tra Vinh Province Buddhist Association has built a
Buddhist school at Phuoc Hoa Pagoda. A first-year class of nearly 30 novice monks has
commenced. This Buddhist school is a branch of the Southern Vietnam Buddhist School.
Among the teachers sent by the central administration, we see Thay Truong Lac and Thay
Tinh Duc.

NAM VIET NUN ASSEMBLY IS BEING ORGANIZED: The Nam Viet Nun Assembly is being
organized for October 6-7, 1956, at Hue Lam Pagoda, Cholon, under the guidance of the
Southern Vietnam Sangha Association.

THE FORMATION OF THE CA MAU PROVINCE SANGHA ASSOCIATION IS IMPENDING: Almost all
provinces have established associations and maintain contact with the Central
Administration. The formation of the Ca Mau Province Sangha Association is underway.
Perhaps Long Xuyen, Rach Gia, and Chau Doc will follow suit.

CONSTRUCTION OF THE XA LOI PAGODA IS UNDERWAY: The fund raised for the
construction of Xa Loi Pagoda has reached two million dong. The construction work is
progressing steadily. The Southern Vietnam Buddhist Association Management Committee is
working with all their heart and strength. Buddhist activities await the contributions
of all benevolent fellow practitioners.

THE DHARMA PROPAGATION WORK IS VIGOROUSLY ADVANCING: Throughout the country,
lecturers and novice monks have dedicated their utmost efforts to the work of Dharma
Propagation. The spirit of study and practice among fellow practitioners in provinces,
for example in Quang Tri, is extraordinarily high. The same is true in the South, where
doctrine classes organized in provinces are enthusiastically supported by the Buddhist
public. The Unified Buddhist Journal has been warmly received in every locality.
